Jarzombek, APL executive director.  ‚ÄúLate fines are a poor incentive for people to bring books back on time. And, they keep people who are unable to pay those fines away from the library. reason_for_stopping_fines: The change in the overdue fine policy was implemented to eliminate any barriers for our patrons to use our libraries and to access the wealth of materials and resources available. policy_notes: A replacement cost will be assessed if an item is not returned within 30 days after its due date. Once the billed item is returned, the replacement cost will be waived.

reason_for_stopping_fines: Fines were never intended to be a source of income," said Penny Neubauer, Director. "Whenwe looked at the data we realized that the problem wasn’t necessarily with things being returnedlate as much as it was with things being checked out and never returned at all. Therefore, weare eliminating the fines for our loyal patrons who may need a couple of extra days to return theitems they have borrowed

For library director Barbara McDade, abolishing daily late fees was a simple solution to a larger problem. The majority of patrons that are late on books are less than one month late, so eliminating a barrier to regular usage for most patrons made sense to the library‚Äôs board of directors, she said.

The decision to end overdue fees came after the library administration and Board of Library Trustees realized that the 11,000 people blocked from taking out books because of unpaid overdue fees came from Berkeley‚Äôs lowest-income zip codes ‚Äî 94702, 94703 and 94710. While charging late fees had originally been meant to encourage people to return books on time, it ended up acting as a barrier to use for many, particularly those with low incomes, according to Elliot Warren, the acting director of the library. ‚ÄúPublic libraries are the people‚Äôs university and we need to make sure they are accessible to everyone,‚Äù said Warren in a statement. ‚ÄúThe current practice unintentionally tells some people they are not welcome.‚Äù
Library Director Nicolle Davies argued that outstanding fines can prevent some patrons from returning to the library, particularly low-income cardholders who can‚Äôt afford to pay.
policy_notes: If a patron doesn't return a book within 42 days of check-out, he or she will be billed for the full cost of the item. And patrons still have to pay any fines accrued before June 20.

reason_for_stopping_fines: By eliminating fines, the library is removing barriers and making access easy, equitable and enjoyable for everyone. ‚ÄúOur libraries are open for the entire community to take advantage of all they have to offer,‚Äù said Contra Costa County Supervisor Karen Mitchoff. ‚ÄúSaying goodbye to fines gives everyone an opportunity to restart their relationship with the library.‚Äù

reason_for_stopping_fines: Our goal is to make sure our patrons can enjoy all of the books, movies, music and services the Library offers, said Tim Kambitsch, Dayton Metro Library Executive Director. ‚ÄúAccumulated overdue fines prevent some patrons from checking out books and other materials. It is more important that materials are returned so that others may borrow them, than it is to charge late fees that can add up and prevent someone from using their Library.‚Äù

Eliminating overdue fines is paramount to providing equitable access for all customers, said City Librarian Michelle Jeske.Too often, fines penalize the most vulnerable families and individuals who can least afford them; we want to reverse this trend and get community members back into our buildings to use materials that enhance their quality of life and education.‚Äù Research shows that the removal of overdue fines can have a dramatic effect of bringing back customers. Similar fine elimination programs have been successfully implemented in other U.S. cities recently, including Salt Lake City and Baltimore.

library_name: Dr. William C. Herrick Community Health Care Library
reason_for_stopping_fines: Studies show that instead of encouraging people to return their items on time, overdue fines, in fact, prevent people from checking out materials in the first place, for fear of accruing fines. As a health care library, we want you to use and benefit from our books and DVDs.

Analysis by the Pratt and other libraries shows that fining customers affects lower-income users disproportionately, and punishes children who might have limited control over returning books on time. About 2,500 of the Pratt‚Äôs blocked cards belong to children and teens.

The branches with the most blocked users are the main library downtown, the Pennsylvania Avenue branch in West Baltimore and the Southeast Anchor Library near Highlandtown. All serve high concentrations of customers living in poverty, who are most in need of the library‚Äôs services, such as access to computers and the internet, help with homework and free classes.

For many, overdue fines and late fees are a barrier that stops children and families from accessing and benefiting from the resources the Fargo Public Library offers. With this initiative, the library hopes to increase access to books and reading, boost literacy and remove barriers for all children in Fargo.  ‚ÄúThe Fargo Public Library is excited to reduce barriers for young readers by removing overdue fines on children‚Äôs items,‚Äù states Library Director Tim Dirks. ‚ÄúThe library‚Äôs strategic plan has identified the reduction of barriers to library services as a major goal for the organization and we look forward to further changes to accomplish this goal.  Research shows that materials are generally returned on time and the lack of fines does encourage youngsters to check out more books."
policy_notes: The library will continue to charge patrons fees for lost, missing or damaged items.

reason_for_stopping_fines: It is the mission of San Jos√© Public Library to provide equal access to information, services, and opportunities that empower, enrich, and enhance the quality of life for all.  Fines are a barrier to that access.

Studies have shown that late fines can be a significant barrier to library access and drive borrowers away, particularly among individuals with low or fixed incomes. Currently, 8% of all San Mateo County Libraries‚Äô 165,000 cardholders currently have their cards blocked due to fines. In our lower-income communities, the number can be as high as 19%. Furthermore, the growing research has shown that fines do not actually incentivize patrons to return materials on time.
